section.title: Introduction
section.para: In Spring Social, a social service such as Twitter or Facebook is modeled as a service provider. With a service provider, an application may create/sever connections and obtain an API through which the application may interact with the service on a user's behalf.

The client-key and client-secret attributes specify the key and secret values assigned to your application when you registered it with the provider.
The class attribute specifies the fully-qualified name of the provider implementation. Spring Social comes with several ready-to-use service provider implementations:

You may also create your own service providers by implementing the ServiceProvider interface or extending either AbstractServiceProvider, AbstractOAuth1ServiceProvider, or AbstractOAuth2ServiceProvider.

section.title: Connection Repository
section.para: In addition to the service provider itself, you'll also need to configure a connection repository bean for service providers to persist connections. Spring Social comes with JdbcConnectionRepository, a connection repository that persists connections to a relational database via JDBC. JdbcConnectionRepository is constructed with a reference to a DataSource through which it will communicate with the database and a TextEncryptor that it will use to encrypt/decrypt sensitive connection details (such as access tokens and secrets).

The TextEncryptor is defined in Spring Security 3.1 in the org.springframework.security.crypto.encrypt package. Spring Security 3.1 also includes an Encryptors class which acts as a factory for common encryptor implementations. section.title: Using Service Providers
section.para: Once you have a server provider configured in Spring, there are a handful of things you can do with the service provider, including:

listitem.para: Manage connections between an application account and a provider profile.
Access provider API for interacting with the service provider on behalf of the user.

section.title: Managing provider connections
section.para: The ServiceProvider interface affords a few methods for managing connections between an application account and a user's profile at the provider:
section.programlisting: boolean isConnected(Serializable accountId); List<ServiceProviderConnection<S>> getConnections(Serializable accountId);
section.para: The isConnected() method is useful for determining if any connections have been made between the user's application account (specified with the account ID) and the provider.

To work with the connections themselves, call the getConnections() method. Notice that this method returns a list of ServiceProviderConnections and not a single connection. That's because it is possible for a user to connect their account with multiple profiles on the provider. For example, if a user has multiple Twitter profiles, any one or all of them may be connected to their local account.

section.title: Creating connections through a service provider
section.para: In addition to the core methods of ServiceProvider, a service provider implementation will give you a connect() method for creating a connection. The connect() will vary depending on whether you are working with an OAuth 1-based service provider or an OAuth 2-based service provider. For an OAuth 1 service provider, the connect() signature is:
To create a connection with an OAuth 1 provider, call it, passing in a local application account ID and an access token that was granted for the profile to be connected to:
section.programlisting: ServiceProviderConnection<?> connection = provider.connect(accountId, new OAuthToken(token, secret));
section.para: The OAuthToken is created given an access token value and the access token secret.
For an OAuth 2 service provider, the connect() signature is slightly different:
OAuth 2 access tokens are not paired with an access token secret. They may, however, come with a refresh token. Therefore, to create a connection with an OAuth 2 provider profile:
section.programlisting: ServiceProviderConnection<?> connection = provider.connect(accountId, new AccessGrant(accessToken, refreshToken));
section.para: In either case, using these methods assumes that you have already gone through the OAuth dance and have obtained an access token. Since the OAuth authorization flow is non-trivial, it's typically best to take advantage of Spring Social's ConnectController (described in ) to handle OAuth authorization and the creation of connections.
